'''John Dee Holman''' often misspelled "Holeman," (born April 4, 1929)<ref name="Music">{{cite web |url=http://www.musicmaker.org/artists_profile/John-Dee-Holeman |title=John Dee Holman |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Musicmaker.org |accessdate=October 22, 2011}}</ref> is an [[United States|American]] [[Piedmont blues]] guitarist, singer, and songwriter.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p371159/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=John Dee Holman |author=Richard Skelly |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 22, 2010}}</ref> His music includes elements of [[Texas blues]], [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] and African American String Band music.<ref name="AMG"/> In his younger days he was also known for his proficiency as a 'buckdancer'.<ref name="NEA"/>

==Biography==
Holman was born in [[Hillsborough, North Carolina]], [[United States]],<ref name="Music"/> but since 1954 he has been based in [[Durham, North Carolina]].<ref name="AMG"/> Inspired by [[Blind Boy Fuller]], Holeman was both singing and playing his guitar at local parties and other events by his mid-teens. By his mid-twenties Holeman had bought his first electric guitar and relocated to Durham, where he played with the pianist, Fris Holloway.<ref name="AMG"/><ref = "Hog">{{cite web |url=http://www.folkstreams.net/principal,372 |title=John Dee Holeman |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Folkstreams.net |accessdate=October 22, 2011}}</ref> The duo became adept at the [[Juba dance]], also known as the hambone or buckdance.

"As a young man, Holman also listened to traveling bluesmen from other areas of the South, to recordings from Chicago and the Delta, and to black and white musicians on the radio. While still a teenager, he started playing music at house parties, Saturday night suppers, and community gatherings throughout his area of rural North Carolina. At country dances, Holman also learned the tradition of "patting juba." Juba, the use of complex hand rhythms to provide timing for dancers, is a centuries-old tradition among Africans and African Americans. Where Holman grew up, it was customary when party musicians took a break for males to engage in competitive solo dancing accompanied only by hand or "patting" rhythms. "Juba" refers to both the complex hand rhythms and the dance traditionally done to them. The dance done to the juba rhythm is also called "buckdance," "bust down," and "jigging." "Patting" is distinguished from clapping by virtue of the varied pitches the patting hand elicits from the arms, chest, thighs, and flanks."
<ref name="NEA">{{cite web |url=http://www.nea.gov/honors/heritage/fellows/fellow.php?id=1988_06&type=bio |title=1988 NEA National Heritage Fellow; John Dee Holman |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Nea.gov |accessdate=October 22, 2011}}</ref>

During his working lifetime, Holman had full-time employment was a construction worker, and music was a part-time pursuit.<ref name="NEA"/> However, 
Holman toured both in the United States and overseas in the 1980s, which included performances at [[New York City|New York]]'s [[Carnegie Hall]], and abroad on behalf of the [[United States Information Agency]]'s 'Arts America' program.<ref name="AMG"/> In 1980, Holeman played at the 42nd [[National Folk Festival (USA)|National Folk Festival]] at [[Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts|Wolf Trap]], [[Virginia]].<ref>{{cite book
| first= Bruce
| last= Bastin
| year= 1995
| title= Red River blues: the blues tradition in the Southeast
| edition= 1st
| publisher= University of Illinois Press 
| location= [[Champaign, Illinois]]
| isbn= 0-252-01213-5
| page= 289}}</ref> He has performed yearly at the Black Banjo Festival in Boone North Carolina. His first album "Bull City After Dark" was nominated for a W.C. Handy award, the Blues equivalent of a Grammy, later renamed "Blues Music Awards."  He recorded his [[album]], ''Bull Durham Blues'' in 1988, which featured [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]]. It was re-released on the [[Music Maker (label)|Music Maker]] [[record label|label]] in 1999. Also in 1988, the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] presented Holman with a [[National Heritage Fellowship]].<ref name="AMG"/>

In 1994, Holman was presented with the [[North Carolina Folk Heritage Award]].<ref name="Music"/> A song he co-wrote with [[Kenny Wayne Shepherd]], "Chapel Hill Boogie", was featured on the 2007 [[Grammy Award]] nominated album, ''[[10 Days Out: Blues from the Backroads]]''.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.variety.com/awardcentral_article/VR1117977173.html?nav=news&categoryid=1983&cs=1 |title=50th annual Grammy Awards nominations (part II) |author= |date= December 6, 2007|work= |publisher=Variety.com |accessdate=October 22, 2011}}</ref>

In 2007, Music Maker also issued the ''John Dee Holeman & the Waifs Band'' album, where Holeman was backed by the Australian [[folk rock]] group,  [[The Waifs]].<ref name="AMG"/>
